title: searching for lightweight serif for drop caps
content: looking for a drop cap which can work with some serif typesetting I'm doing. 3 line single character in conjunction with some DTL typefaces (paradox) and the drop cap just comes in so strong. Trajan is the only one I can think of which is very light but even that comes in very fat when blown up 300%; anyone have thoughts? I'm looking for a light and airy look for the entire piece.
author: avisualperson

comments.content:
Maybe you should go all out? :-)  
 [http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/emigre/missionary/](http://web.archive.org/web/20100131080519/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/emigre/missionary/ "http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/emigre/missionary/")

If you need light fonts, instead of really thin ones it's usually better to use "inline" ones: fonts that have the insides cut out. And if you're using a DTL face, Cristal pops into my mind:  
 [http://www.flickr.com/photos/bielerpress/258240026/](http://web.archive.org/web/20100131080519/http:/www.flickr.com/photos/bielerpress/258240026/ "http://www.flickr.com/photos/bielerpress/258240026/")

Or maybe something even lighter (not  
to mention more accessible!) like this:  
 [http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/paratype/lidia/](http://web.archive.org/web/20100131080519/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/paratype/lidia/ "http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/paratype/lidia/")
